questions.question_text: Which option is a valid IPv6 address?

comments.content: Got it, answer D has only 6 hextet (96 bit). A valid ipv6 must have 8 hextet (128 bit)

discussion.content: Can't get this. Why is D wrong?

questions.answer_description: To use IPv6 on your router, you must, at a minimum, enable the protocol and assign IPv6 addresses to your interfaces.

choices.B: An IPv4 address must be configured.
choices.D: IPv6 must be enabled with the ipv6 enable command in global configuration mode.
choices.A: An IPv6 address must be configured on the interface.
choices.C: Stateless autoconfiguration must be enabled after enabling IPv6 on the interface.

discussion.content: Sorry A is correct miss read the Question

questions.question_text: What is one requirement for interfaces to run IPv6?
Which MTU size can cause a baby giant error?

Instructions -
This item contains several questions that you must answer. You can view these questions by clicking on the corresponding button to the left. Changing questions can be accomplished by clicking the numbers to the left question. In order to complete the questions, you will need to refer to the topology.
To gain access to the topology, click on the topology button of the screen. When you have finished viewing the topology, you can return to your questions by clicking on the Questions button to the left.
Each of the windows can be minimized by clicking on the [-]. You can also reposition a window by dragging it by the title bar.

Scenario -
Refer to the topology. The diagram represents a small network with a single connection to the Internet.
//IMG//

If the router R1 has a packet with a destination address 192.168.1.255, what describes the operation of the network?

choices.A: R1 will forward the packet out all interfaces.
choices.C: As R1 forwards the frame containing this packet, Sw-A will add 192.168.1.255 to its MAC table.
choices.B: R1 will drop this packet because this it is not a valid IP address.
choices.E: As R1 forwards the frame containing this packet, Sw-A will forward it to the device assigned the IP address of 192.168.1.255. B
choices.D: R1 will encapsulate the packet in a frame with a destination MAC address of FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF.

comments.content: Routers do not forward broadcast traffic. That's why IP helper command address needs to be configured in order for DHCP clients to receive IP addresses.

discussion.content: It says the answer is B. Why not A? Is that not a Broadcast address?
